page.title: 10Farming (Romney Marsh)
page.content: The land is bisected by the Royal Military Canal above which the escarpment rises to sixty metres and is mainly rough grazing for cattle and sheep with some broad leaved woodland. To the seaward side of the canal is ancient reclaimed marsh still partly traditionally farmed with sheep on permanent pasture. But in the last fifty years more than half the acreage has been under the plough and is down to cereals with oil seed rape and potatoes as break crops, returning in rotation to grazing with new leys. Here you will find the traditional hardy Romney Marsh sheep which still lamb in the open protected only by wattle sheep folds. Dykes were originally excavated for drainage but now serve as field boundaries as well as for irrigation.
